from fundamental physical constants

Fundamental physical constants govern key effects in high-energy particle physics and astro-
physics, including the stability of particles, nuclear reactions, formation and evolution of stars,
synthesis of heavy nuclei and emergence of stable molecular structures. Here, we show that fun-
damental constants also set an upper bound for the frequency of phonons in condensed matter
phases, or how rapidly an atom can vibrate in these phases. This bound is in agreement with ab
initio simulations of atomic hydrogen and high-temperature hydride superconductors, and implies
an upper limit to the superconducting transition temperature Tc in condensed matter. Fundamental
constants set this limit to the order of 102 − 103 K. This range is consistent with our calculations
of Tc from optimal Eliashberg functions. As a corollary, we observe that the very existence of the
current research of finding Tc at and above 300 K is due to the observed values of fundamental
constants. We finally discuss how fundamental constants affect the observability and operation of
other effects and phenomena including phase transitions.

I. INTRODUCTION

The governing role of fundamental physical constants
has been extensively discussed in high-energy particle
physics and astrophysics. Examples include the stabil-
ity of nuclei, nuclear reactions, and the formation and
evolution of stars – where heavy elements are produced
and give rise to other observable structures. In these
and other processes, fundamental constants give the Uni-
verse its observed properties and separate it from poten-
tial other universes where these constants may be dif-
ferent [1–9]. Understanding the origin of fundamental
constants and their fine-tuning is considered one of the
grand challenges in science [10, 11]. Approaching this
challenge starts with deepening our understanding of how
fundamental constants affect phenomena spanning the
length and energy scales between particle physics and
astrophysics [12–14].

In condensed matter physics and in other areas that
support a continuum description of matter, such as elas-
ticity and hydrodynamics, system properties are driven
by many-body collective effects. These effects are of-

∗k.trachenko@qmul.ac.uk

ten considered as emergent and thus not reducible to
individual particles whose properties are set by funda-
mental constants. It was therefore unexpected when
it was discovered that fundamental constants govern
the bounds, characteristic values and properties of sev-
eral key many-body collective processes. Examples in-
clude viscosity [15–17], diffusion and spin dynamics [18–
22], electron and heat transport [23–26], thermal conduc-
tivity in insulators [27] and conductors [13], the speed
of sound [28], elastic moduli including those in lower-
dimensional systems [12, 13], thermal expansion, melt-
ing [29, 30] and velocity gradients that can be set up in
cells using biochemical energy [31]. In these examples,
properties are governed by either fundamental constants
only or by a combination of these constants with other
parameters such as temperature. The implications of
these findings extend to both fundamental and applied
science [12].

Here, we show that fundamental physical constants
provide an upper bound to the frequency of phonons in
condensed matter phases, setting a limit to the vibra-
tional frequency of atoms in these phases. This bound
involves the dimensionless electron-to-proton mass ratio
β, the key constant involved in setting the finely-tuned
“habitable zone” of our world in the (α, β) space, where
α is the fine-structure constant [1]. The bound applies

II. METHODS

In our density functional theory calculations, we use
similar methods to our earlier paper [28]. This includes
using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-
correlation functional [32], an energy cutoff of 1200 eV
and a k-point grid of spacing 2π × 0.025 Å−1 to sample
the electronic Brillouin zone.

We relax cell parameters and internal coordinates to
obtain a pressure to within 10−4 GPa of the target pres-
sure and forces smaller than 10−5 eV/Å. We calculate the
phonon dispersion using the finite displacement method
[33] in conjunction with nondiagonal supercells [34] with
a 4× 4× 4 coarse q-point grid to sample the vibrational
Brillouin zone. We use Fourier interpolation to calculate
the phonon frequencies along a high symmetry path in
the Brillouin zone.

Below is an in-depth look at the key ideas, methods, results, and implications of the paper “Upper bounds on the highest phonon frequency and superconducting temperature from fundamental physical constants” by Trachenko et al. (J. Phys.: Condens. Matter, in press). I’ll first summarize the motivation and main findings, then walk through the derivations, computational methods, and broader consequences.

---

## 1. Motivation and Context

1. **Role of Fundamental Constants in Physics.** 
   - It is well-understood that fundamental physical constants (e.g., the speed of light \(c\), Planck’s constant \(\hbar\), electron charge \(e\), electron mass \(m_e\), proton mass \(m_p\), and so on) play pivotal roles in particle physics and astrophysics. Classic examples include stellar formation, fusion processes, nuclear stability, and heavy-element synthesis.  
   - Over the last decade, research has also revealed that certain upper or lower bounds in condensed matter can be set by combinations of fundamental constants. Examples include lower bounds on viscosity, upper bounds on the speed of sound, and minimal thermal conductivity in insulators.

2. **Upper Bound on Phonon Frequencies.** 
   - In crystalline or non-crystalline solids, atoms vibrate with characteristic frequencies known as phonons. The highest of these frequencies (often near the Debye frequency) determines many thermodynamic and transport properties.  
   - The question the authors ask is: “Is there a theoretical maximum phonon frequency for atomic vibrations in condensed phases, and if so, can it be expressed purely in terms of fundamental constants?”

3. **Implications for Superconductivity.**  
   - A fundamental limit on the highest phonon frequency would directly impact phonon-mediated superconductivity, because superconducting critical temperature \(T_c\) in conventional, electron-phonon-driven superconductors is roughly proportional to certain averages of the phonon frequencies.  
   - Consequently, identifying an upper frequency cap places a ceiling on how large \(T_c\) can become in phonon-based superconductors (e.g., H\(_3\)S, LaH\(_{10}\), CaH\(_6\), etc.).  
   - Interestingly, they argue that even for non-phonon pairing mechanisms (e.g., electron-electron pairing in cuprates), fundamental constants still indirectly impose a broad upper limit.

---

## 2. Main Results

### 2.1 Upper Bound on the Maximum Phonon Frequency

- **Derivation of the bound.**  
  The starting point is the approximate relationship for a non-molecular condensed phase in which each atom of mass \(m\) vibrates with some highest energy scale \(E\) set by chemical bonding. Roughly, one can view the maximum phonon frequency \(\omega_m\) as
  \[
    \hbar\omega_m \;\sim\; \sqrt{\frac{E}{m\,a^2}}\,a^2
    \;=\; \sqrt{\frac{E}{m}},
  \]
  where \(a\) is an interatomic spacing and \(E\) a bonding energy. They then use:
  1. The Bohr radius \(a_B\) sets a basic lower-limit to atomic separations in dense phases.
  2. The Rydberg energy \(E_R\approx 13.6\,\text{eV}\) is an upper scale for typical electronic bonding.  

  Substituting \(m\rightarrow m_p\) (proton mass, relevant for the lightest possible atom) and \(E \rightarrow E_R\) yields (dropping numerical factors of order unity):
  \[
    \hbar \omega_m 
    \;\sim\; E_R\,\sqrt{\frac{m_e}{m_p}}
    \;\approx\; 3680\,\text{K}.
  \]
  Written more explicitly, they obtain:
  \[
    \omega_m^{u} \;=\;
    \frac{1}{32\pi^2 \varepsilon_0^2}\;\frac{m_e e^4}{\hbar^3}\;\sqrt{\frac{m_e}{m_p}}
    \;\sim\; 3680\,\text{K}.
  \]
  - This numerical value, \(\sim 3000\!-\!4000\,\text{K}\) (when expressed as a temperature equivalent), is the “fundamental bound” on the maximum phonon frequency for non-molecular condensed phases at **zero pressure**.

- **Effect of high pressure.**  
  Hydrogen only becomes a dense atomic crystal above \(\sim\!400\) GPa. To account for additional energy contributions under large pressure \(P\), one includes \(P\,V\) in the energy budget. The authors show that a notional correction raises the zero-pressure bound slightly when \(P\) is large, but never so dramatically as to exceed \(\sim\!5000$–$6000\,\text{K}\) in the extreme. This means that even under huge pressures, the fundamental bound does not jump to extremely large frequencies.

- **DFT calculations confirm the bound.**  
  They directly test the maximum phonon frequency for atomic metallic hydrogen (the lightest possible dense phase) via **density functional theory** (DFT) at various pressures (400–1000 GPa).  
  - The *calculated* maximum frequency in atomic hydrogen at 400 GPa is just above 3600 K, indeed right below the predicted fundamental bound. 
  - They also examine hydrogen-rich hydrides (H\(_3\)S, LaH\(_{10}\), CaH\(_6\), MgIrH\(_6\), etc.) because these systems have very high phonon frequencies. Their maximum frequencies stay below or around the same 3000–4000 K corridor, in accord with the theoretical limit.

- **Molecular solids can have ‘vibron’ modes** exceeding the typical bond energies, but the authors note that even for H\(_2\) molecules, the highest intra-molecular modes remain \(\lesssim\!6200\)–\(6400\,\text{K}\). Thus if one wants to unify the bound so that it also accommodates “molecular vibron” modes, they propose doubling the figure (\(\approx 7360\,\text{K}\)) to cover that special case. Nonetheless, for *non-molecular* condensed matter phases, \(\sim 3000$–$4000\,\text{K}\) stands as the robust figure.

### 2.2 Implications for Superconductivity

- **Conventional electron-phonon mechanisms.**  
  In standard Migdal-Eliashberg (ME) theory, the superconducting transition temperature \(T_c\) scales roughly with an average phonon frequency \(\omega\):
  \[
    T_c \approx \; C \;\omega,
  \]
  where \(C\) is a function of the electron-phonon coupling \(\lambda\), Coulomb pseudopotential \(\mu^*\), and other details.  
  - Empirically and theoretically, there is a limit to how large \(\lambda\) can become before the system becomes unstable. With typical \(\lambda \approx 1$–$2\) near the threshold of lattice instabilities, the coefficient \(C\) is not extremely large (\(\sim 0.1$–$0.3\)).
  - Consequently, if \(\omega\) cannot exceed \(\omega_m^u\sim 3000$–$4000\,\text{K}\), there is an ultimate upper bound on \(T_c\), typically on the order of a few hundred Kelvin:
    \[
      T_c^u \;=\; C\,\omega_m^u \;\sim\; 10^2\!-\!10^3\,\text{K}.
    \]

- **Numerical optimization of the Eliashberg function.**  
  The paper supports that statement with a direct optimization:  
  1. They impose the maximum frequency cutoff \(\omega_m^u\).  
  2. They fix \(\lambda\) to a high yet physically acceptable value (e.g. \(\lambda=2\)).  
  3. They numerically vary the shape of the Eliashberg spectral density \(\alpha^2F(\omega)\) to maximize the solution of the ME equations for \(T_c\).  
  4. The solution converges to \(T_c \sim 600\,\text{K}\) for that scenario, right in the 300–1000 K region predicted analytically.

- **Non-phonon mechanisms.**  
  Even for unconventional superconductors (e.g. cuprates, with electron-electron pairing), the Fermi energy \(E_F\) can serve as the fundamental energy scale, and \(E_F\) also ultimately depends on fundamental constants such as \(\hbar\), \(m_e\), and \(e^2/(4\pi\varepsilon_0)\). This again leads to a broad limiting scale for \(T_c\).  

### 2.3 Observability of Phenomena and Broader Consequences

- **Were constants different...**  
  They remark that if the dimensionless mass ratio \(\beta=m_e/m_p\) or other fundamental constants were drastically different, the maximum phonon frequency might be too high or too low relative to ambient temperatures. Hence:
  - If \(\omega_m^u \) were tiny, one would never observe superconductivity above micro-K temperatures, making it effectively unobservable in normal planetary contexts.  
  - If \(\omega_m^u \) were extremely large, we could have stable superconductors at millions of Kelvin, or no stable condensed phases at typical conditions.  

- **Phase transitions, melting, and more.**  
  The authors propose that fundamental constants shape not only superconductivity but also whether certain phase transitions (classical vs. quantum) can occur at planetary temperatures. For instance, if the Debye frequency in solids is always far above typical thermal energies, the atomic vibrations would remain quantum-mechanical under all usual conditions, and classical (entropy-driven) transitions might vanish or become unobservable.

---

## 3. Methods Overview

1. **Density Functional Theory (DFT).**  
   - Uses the plane-wave code *CASTEP*, with exchange-correlation approximations (PBE functional).  
   - High cutoffs (e.g. 1200 eV) and dense \(\mathbf{k}\)-point sampling to achieve good convergence for high-pressure hydrides and hydrogen.  
   - Pressure is adjusted until the target structure (e.g., the atomic I4\(_1\)/amd phase of hydrogen, or various superhydride structures) reaches stable pressure within \(<10^{-4}\) GPa.  
   - Phonons are computed via the finite-displacement method or by computing force-constant matrices in suitably sized supercells.

2. **Migdal-Eliashberg Calculations.**  
   - They solve the isotropic Migdal-Eliashberg equations, using the spectral function \(\alpha^2F(\omega)\) as the primary input.  
   - They fix the electron-phonon coupling \(\lambda\) to typical large values (1–2) then vary the shape of \(\alpha^2F(\omega)\) under the constraint that the phonon frequencies cannot exceed \(\omega_m^u\).  
   - The maximum possible \(T_c\) for that family of functions sets the theoretical ceiling.

---

## 4. Significance and Implications

1. **Establishing a “Fundamental Cap” on Phonon Frequencies.**  
   The main conceptual takeaway is that *if you try to maximize atomic vibrational frequencies in stable, non-molecular condensed matter, you still hit a limit that is purely set by \(\hbar,\,m_e,\,m_p,\,e\), etc.*. Numerically, this is a few thousand Kelvin at zero pressure.

2. **Upper Bound on Superconducting \(T_c\).**  
   With that cap in place, the highest \(\omega\)-based superconductor can only reach a \(T_c\) in the few-hundred Kelvin range—plausibly up to a bit above room temperature (300–400 K, maybe a few hundred K more), but not thousands of Kelvin.  
   - This clarifies why present-day searches for room-temperature superconductors (like hydrides at high pressure) are “within range” but are not likely to leap to thousands-of-Kelvin superconductors.

3. **Connection to Universality and Fine-Tuning.**  
   This paper extends an anthropic/fine-tuning narrative to condensed matter: *the Universe’s choice* of \(\alpha\), \(\beta\), \(\hbar\), etc., not only sets up nuclear and stellar phenomena but also delimits whether high-\(T_c\) superconductivity can exist at or above everyday temperatures.

4. **Future Directions.**  
   - More systematic study of bounding \(\lambda\) and how that interacts with \(\omega_{\mathrm{max}}\).  
   - Examination of whether “exotic” superconducting mechanisms might circumvent the frequency bound—though the authors argue fundamental constants would still appear in the relevant energy scales.  
   - Linking other phases or transitions (melting lines, quantum vs. classical transitions) to fundamental constants in a unified picture that spans nuclear scales, condensed matter, and astrophysics.

---

## 5. Summary of the Paper’s Contribution

- **They analytically derive** an upper limit on \(\omega_m\) (the maximum phonon frequency) purely from fundamental constants, anchored by the electron-to-proton mass ratio \(m_e/m_p\) and the Rydberg energy scale.  
- **They confirm** this limit using ab initio calculations of atomic hydrogen (the lightest possible element, which should maximize phonon frequencies at high pressures) and also check a range of hydrogen-rich superhydrides.  
- **They then use** the conventional Migdal-Eliashberg framework (plus an instability-based argument that \(\lambda\) cannot grow arbitrarily large) to show that the maximum superconducting temperature \(T_c\) must lie in the broad range of a few hundred Kelvin (roughly \(100\!-\!1000\,\mathrm{K}\)). Numerically, they find \(\sim 600\,\mathrm{K}\) is achievable only if one pushes all spectral weight to the highest allowed frequencies.  
- **They discuss** how a different set of fundamental constants could have trivialized or precluded the search for room-temperature (or higher) superconductivity, underscoring that *the search for 300 K superconductivity is itself possible because of the particular fundamental constants we observe*.

In short, the paper’s core message is that fundamental constants not only set familiar high-energy or nuclear thresholds but also impose a universal limit to atomic vibration speeds and, by extension, a universal upper bound on phonon-mediated superconducting \(T_c\). This applies across dense matter, especially for hydrogen-based or hydrogen-dominant superconductors that aim for the highest \(T_c\). It thereby provides a “fundamental lens” on today’s pursuit of room-temperature superconductivity in superhydrides and beyond.

---

### 1. **Structure Prediction and Materials Screening**

1. **High-throughput search**  
   - Superconductors at high pressure or with intricate structures can exist in enormous compositional and structural “phase spaces.” AI/ML tools can guide and accelerate exploration of these spaces.  
   - By mapping chemical composition, potential stoichiometries, and structural parameters into model predictions (e.g., predicted enthalpy of formation or superconducting descriptors), AI can rapidly filter out unpromising candidates, leaving a smaller subset for more expensive calculations or experiments.

   - Classical methods such as random structure searching or evolutionary algorithms (CALYPSO, USPEX, etc.) can be enhanced with AI-based heuristics.  
   - Reinforcement-learning approaches can iteratively propose candidate structures, learn from each attempt, and direct the search more intelligently than purely random sampling.

3. **Generative models**  
   - Deep generative models (variational autoencoders or generative adversarial networks) can learn global features of known superconductors and then “generate” novel candidate materials.  
   - This approach can be combined with theoretical constraints (e.g., charge neutrality, realistic atomic sizes) to propose physically plausible new compounds.

---

### 2. **Accelerating Ab Initio Calculations**

1. **ML Surrogates**  
   - Density functional theory (DFT) and Migdal-Eliashberg calculations are computationally expensive, especially for large supercells.  
   - Machine-learned surrogate models can approximate energies, phonon spectra, electron-phonon coupling parameters, and other key quantities with much lower computational cost once trained on a modest set of quantum calculations.

2. **Active Learning and Bayesian Optimization**  
   - By iteratively training ML models on the most “informative” data points—selected using an “acquisition function” that searches for high uncertainty or high predicted \(T_c\)—AI can zero in on high-value materials with fewer expensive ab initio runs.

3. **Inverse Design**  
   - In “inverse design,” one specifies target properties (e.g., a certain superconducting transition temperature or a minimal required electron-phonon coupling) and then uses ML-based optimization to propose chemical/structural configurations that match those properties.  
   - This approach moves beyond brute-force scanning and directly aims to achieve a high \(T_c\) under specific constraints, such as ambient pressure stability.

---

### 3. **Data-Driven Insights into Superconductivity**

1. **Pattern recognition in existing databases**  
   - Large materials databases (e.g., the Materials Project, OQMD, and superconductor-focused repositories) contain a wealth of experimental and computed results.  
   - AI can detect subtle correlations among chemical composition, crystal structure, electron band topology, phonon dispersions, and observed \(T_c\). These correlations may be too subtle for straightforward “human” inspection but can reveal valuable design heuristics.

2. **Explainable AI methods**  
   - Beyond black-box predictions, “explainable” AI techniques (SHAP values, feature-attribution methods, etc.) can highlight which structural or chemical features most affect predicted \(T_c\).  
   - This can help guide researchers toward specific design motifs or doping strategies, shedding light on the underlying physics.

---

### 4. **Discovery of New Superconducting Mechanisms**

1. **Unconventional superconductors**  
   - While phonon-driven pairing is well-described by Migdal-Eliashberg theory, many high-\(T_c\) superconductors (e.g. cuprates, iron pnictides) involve more complex mechanisms. AI can capture correlations in multi-orbital or strongly correlated systems by learning from data (experimental or high-level quantum approaches).  
   - Large-scale ML analyses might detect patterns in doping phase diagrams, spin-fluctuation spectra, or electronic instabilities that precede superconductivity.

2. **Automated literature analysis**  
   - Text-mining and natural-language processing can help synthesize the vast superconductivity literature, highlighting overlooked compounds, extracting experimental conditions, or inferring “hidden” patterns from thousands of articles and patents.

---

### 5. **Automated Experimentation and Robotics**

1. **Robotic synthesis**  
   - “Self-driving” labs integrate AI with robotic materials synthesis and characterization.  
   - An AI agent proposes a new composition and synthesis pathway, the robot fabricates and measures it, and the AI then updates its model. This closed-loop approach can rapidly converge on target superconducting phases or doping levels.  

2. **Accelerated characterization**  
   - Rapid scanning of temperature- or pressure-dependent properties, combined with real-time machine-learning analysis, can identify signals of superconductivity and optimize conditions for sample preparation.

---

### 6. **Challenges and Outlook**

- **Accuracy and Transferability.**  
  - ML models remain only as good as their training data. For truly novel, complex materials (e.g., those far outside known chemistries), the model might extrapolate poorly.

  - AI can propose thousands of candidates, but validating them—experimentally or via advanced theory—takes time and resources. Careful synergy between rapid ML screening and rigorous ab initio or experimental validation is crucial.

  - Especially in unconventional superconductors, a big challenge is *why* a certain structure is predicted to have a high \(T_c\). Combined “explainable AI + theory” helps solidify those insights into new design principles.
